title: Desperate Housewives’ Felicity Huffman turns begins 14-day sentence
text:
Felicity Huffman has begun her sentence (Picture: AP Photo/Elise Amendola)

Desperate Housewives star Felicity Huffman has reportedly turned herself into the police to begin a 14-day sentence over the college admissions bribery scandal.

Last month, the 56-year-old was sentenced after pleading guilty to paying $15,000 (£12,100) to doctor her older daughter Sophia’s university entrance exams, without the youngster’s knowledge.

According to TMZ, Felicity arrived at the Federal Correctional Institution in Dublin, California – near San Francisco – on Tuesday to begin her two-week sentence.

A judge handed Felicity 14 days in jail, a $30,000 (£23,300) fine, one-year of supervised release and 250 hours of community service.

Judge Indira Talwani told Felicity at the sentencing: ‘I don’t think anyone wants to be going to prison. ‘I do think this is the right sentence here. You move forward and you can rebuild your life after this. You pay your dues.’

Felicity also spoke at the hearing and said: ‘I am deeply sorry to the students, parents, colleges and universities who have been impacted by my actions.

‘I am sorry to my daughter, Sophia, my daughter, Georgia, and my husband, Bill. I have betrayed them all.’

The actress pleaded guilty (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Felicity’s actor husband William H Macy wrote a letter that was read out in court, to explain how their family dynamic has changed in light of the scandal.

The Shameless star said Felicity’s relationship with their daughters Sophia and Georgia ‘exploded on March 12th’ when the news became public.

William wrote: ‘Rebuilding that relationship will be a long process but I also want you to know Felicity has raised two amazing young women.’

Some of Felicity’s Desperate Housewives co-stars, including Eva Longoria and creator Marc Cherry, also wrote letters in defence of her character.

But her former colleague, Ricardo Chivara, accused her of ‘white privilege’.

He tweeted: ‘White Privilege. And I saw Eight years worth of it, so I know what I’m talking about. Accountability and Responsibility don’t mean shit to these people.’
